captions.text: You ever get the feeling that the big fancy

ship we've had so much fun on over the years
has started sitting a bit lower in the water

than it used to?
And when we bring our concerns to the captain,

we find him doubled over with his pants round
his ankles and his nose shoved up his asshole

'cos he was curious to know if it's possible
to survive by breathing your own farts?

I've been feeling that way about the triple-A
sector of the industry for some time now.

What isn't a sequel is a knock-off and what
isn't a knock-off is a reboot and what isn't

a reboot is a remastering, even a dog chasing
its own tail has the sense not to bite it

off and try to sell it as a draught excluder.
Still, I'll take a remasterbate over a rebooty

call 'cos like all culture games exist as
a historical record that can teach us a lot

about technology and attitudes of the past,
all of which is lost if you remake it every

ten years with all-new gritty realism and
testicle physics.

I always appreciate the kind of remastering
that lets you see how far we've come, with

the special button that turns the graphics
back to the original low-res version like
you've opened a gateway to the lego dimension.

But the games that do get remastered and preserved
thusly are getting picked pretty fucking arbitrarily,

in what seems to be a fucking open season
on remasterings.

Resident Evil, a poster child for ageing poorly
second only to Macauley Culkin?

Fahrenheit: Indigo Prophecy Remastered? In
order for something to be remastered, it has

to have been mastered in the first place;
the most you can do with Fahrenheit is re-bollocks

it up.
But on the positive side we have Grim Fandango

Remastered.
Which I'm going to cover fully because the

original would've been a prime candidate for
retro review if it could have been persuaded

to run on any computer built after the turn
of the millennium.

Grim Fandango is an adventure game created
by Tim Schafer back in his LucasArts days,

and remains officially the last original thought
anyone has had even within earshot of LucasArts.

It's now been clawed from the Sarlacc pit
and re-released by Tim Schafer's Double Fine

with all-new remastered graphics, by which
I mean the same graphics but the models have
better definition.

Although considering that all the characters
look like they're wearing paper bag skull

masks, definition was never really an issue,
there, and there was a limit to how much the

pre-rendered baked-in background art could
be zhuzhed up, so it still looks like a 3D

modelling portfolio by someone who refuses
to move on from the Amiga 1200.

Alternative control schemes have also been
added, since this was back before there was

as much competition for your time and you
could say "You'll take our tank controls and

fucking like them, player."
Both alternatives have their issues, of course.

With mouse controls you run by double clicking,
but it doesn't work when you're clicking on

an interactable object which are the only
reason to move anywhere.

Using a controller with the camera-based controls
has the usual issue when the camera is constantly

changing angle and position, causing the main
character to suddenly spin on his heel as

it does so like he just walked into a brothel
and saw his future father-in-law.

And when you get into a vehicle suddenly all
bets are off what pushing analog stick will

do, unless you bet that it will not be whatever
you wanted it to do.

But I don't want to harp at it for not being
remastered enough, 'cos as I said preservation

is the important part and it's heartening
just for it to be available to everyone who

might never have been able to play it before,
kind of the opposite problem to what Fahrenheit

has, which is finding anyone that might WANT
to have played it before.

On that note, the attitude of preservation
is taken to an admirable degree in Grim Fandango

Remastered; the original was completely bugged
up the arse as well.

Glitches accelerated as the game went on and
I had a nice juicy crash and forced reboot

some ways in. Now I know why the game opened
with a message saying "Hey, there's no death

or failure state but maybe you should frequently
save anyway, wink wink tap nose.

Yes, we have heard of autosave, but we don't
want you getting complacent.

You know how it goes, Autosaves one day, sudden
spike in the infant death rate the next."

Well that about wraps up the technical side
of things, let's move onto the more interesting
question: does Grim Fandango still hold up?

It's set in the Aztec afterlife through which
the dead must journey for four years to reach

eternal rest, and we play as Manny Calavera,
a travel agent whose job is to sell travel

upgrade packages to the newly dead.
Kind of a plot hole here 'cos the quality

of the travel package is supposed to be based
on how good they were in life, so I don't

see how he'd be able to upgrade them, there's
a rather hasty throwaway line concerning 'the

money you were buried with' but I don't see
how two coins on your eyelids will fund much

more than a trip to the snack machine.
Anyway, Manny's attempts to cheat the system

gets an innocent woman tied up in a sinister
plot, and he must embark upon his own four

year journey to find her and gain redemption.
Now, I've been increasingly down on adventure

games over the years 'cos they're just linear
stories broken up with glorified keyhunting

puzzles often riding a train of logic that
took on a few too many passengers at Batshit-on-sea,

but Grim Fandango demonstrates how to juice
that particular lemon - it's just a matter

of using them to further the story rather
than interrupt it.

Pour exampler, the high spot of the game is
year two, when Manny is running a nightclub

in a gambling town.
From one dry objective of securing passage

on the next ship out, the usual chain of 'use
thing on thing to get next thing', is threaded

through a showcase of colourful intrigues
and characters that Manny's gotten to know

over the last year and it paints him as much
more likeable and savvy than the standard

adventure game stock clueless twat.
Bit of a story-gameplay clash at one point

when Manny witnesses the murder and tragic
death scene of a friend, and then, after composing

himself, blackmails the murderer into letting
him steal some fucking tools.

I suppose it works with Manny's overall redemptive
character arc, but it's kinda short-sighted

for a guy with no eyes.
And the game never gets back to that level,

kinda loses steam from the ship section onwards,
ironically. The last two years get a bit hasty

and scrappy.
Not a deal breaker, but if like me you get

most of the way through and the game crashes
half an hour after the last save, it might

be what makes you pack it in.
"Fuck it, I basically remember how it ends.

If I wanted to start gambling on crash likelihood
I'd buy a supersaver package on Malaysia Airlines."

title: Grim Fandango - Does It Hold Up? (Zero Punctuation)

the walking stick or being shipped like a package.﻿

comments.author: Padruig9

comments.text:
This game really examplifies the main problem with puzzle adventures. In 
normal puzzles you are given some options, and have to figure out how to 
use those options to get to your objective; the rook moves like this, now 
capture the king. In this game I solved every puzzle the moment I figured 
out what my options were, and the actual challenge was just figuring out 
what I could do. I can't really say with a straight face that this game had 
puzzles at all, the entire gameplay was just dicking around trying to find 
the missing piece that will make the solution obvious. I gave up a few 
times and consulted a walkthrough, and in retrospect that was entirely the 
right decision.﻿

comments.author: Shaun Power

comments.text:
Well I feel sad for the game, not because it is a overlooked good game. But 
it was because of the game being developed by a developer who has lost his 
mind over the years that I feel sad for the game.

You see, this is why it is not a smart idea for game developers to be on 
social media.

Mario, Zelda and even Pokemon games would forever be remembered for being 
great games, because the developers who made them would retire and go 
unnoticed, turn up for some gaming events, quietly go away until they die 
and we mourn over their passing by paying tribute to their wonderful games.

The game Grim Fandango will sadly not receive the same treatment, because 
when the developer passes away it won't be the game that would be 
remembered, it would be the developer's hurtful comments towards the 
audience that played their game long ago that don't want anything to do 
with him now.

So this is why I cry for this game, not because it was an overlooked 
classic, but because of how far the original developer has fallen.﻿

comments.text:
I went back to Indiana Jones and the Fate of Atlantis when it came on 
steam... and I honestly don't know how my 12 year old self did it.  I guess 
I had more patience since there weren't 12,000 games a click away for me on 
Steam, but seriously... the answer to a puzzle in a room is to go across 
the street to get a jar so that I can use 'what seems like expired 
mayonnaise" to light a rope on fire so that...

...Ugh, even typing it out makes me tired.  Sometimes I think the magic of 
something comes from, well, being 12.  That said, most "adventure games" 
are just a kick in the groin to actual intuition, deductive skill, or 
general cognition.﻿

comments.author: Mike DiLoreto

comments.text:
Big problem with your plot summary: Manny isn't a travel agent. He's a 
travel guide. As in, he's the guy stuck shlepping along the four-year 
journeys with all the stiffs that have already signed up for it by being 
dick-waffles.

So he cons his way into escorting an absolute saint of a woman so he can do 
one of those advance-directly-to-nirvana quickies, but ends up stuck during 
another four-year-shlep anyway -- the first clue Manny gets that the 
afterlife bureaucracy has been fucking him over.﻿

I don't remember Grim Fandango crashing that frequently (the original one 
that is) but I'm kind of surprised they didn't fix something like that - 
did they have no one available in office to say, actually go through the 
story to see if they were any glaringly obvious problems that the player 
would face.

If you're going to "remaster" anything make sure the player can actually 
run what you're planning on "remaking" them play is the obvious lesson that 
SHOULD be taken away from this.

Hardly a remastered game if it needs patching is it?﻿

even worse tendency to fall in love with their own press than Hollywood 
types - hence the rolling mess that is Molyneux. 

Both of them have effectively demonstrated the utter bullshit that 
Kickstarter is in such curious clarity that I'm still amazed when people 
want to insist that it is anything but a pre-production pre-order platform 
wherein the project lead should assume all risk due to both FTA and 
contract law. ﻿
